I think there might be some confusion here. You mentioned earlier that you inherited a vintage Omega Seamaster watch, but now you're talking about a great-grandfather's antique violin and an 18th-century Chinese vase. I'm happy to help you with your questions, but I want to clarify that it's essential to work with experts who specialize in specific areas to get accurate appraisals.

For your antique violin, it's great that you've scheduled an appointment with a local expert. Since they specialize in violins, they'll be able to assess the instrument's authenticity, condition, and value.

However, for your 18th-century Chinese vase, it's generally recommended to find a separate expert who specializes in Asian antiques. Asian art and antiques require a distinct set of knowledge and expertise, and a violin expert might not have the necessary familiarity with Chinese ceramics.

It's best to find an expert who has a proven track record in appraising and authenticating Asian antiques, particularly Chinese ceramics from the 18th century. This will ensure that you receive an accurate appraisal and avoid any potential misidentification or undervaluation.

You can search for experts in Asian antiques through organizations like the Appraisers Association of America (AAA), the International Society of Appraisers (ISA), or the Asian Art Dealers Association of America (AADA), as I mentioned earlier. You can also ask for referrals from reputable dealers, auction houses, or museums that specialize in Asian art and antiques.

Remember to research the expert's credentials, read reviews, and ask questions before scheduling an appointment. It's essential to work with someone who has the necessary expertise to accurately assess your item.
